prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for throwing an unwanted party?
So next week is my best friend's birthday and i decided to throw him a surprise party. Everyone was excited and everything was cool untill today.

We talked today just us 2, and i asked him what he is doing for his bday, he said that if said that hes glad theres no party and if there was one he would be mad af. (The party is at his house so hes just gonna be extra mad)

He said he hates birthday parties many times before but i thought he was just saying that so hr won't be dissapointed if theres no party.

Ive been planning this party for a long time and its way too late to cancel. 

AITA for not listening to him and doing whatever i want?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The person is asking if they're in the wrong for throwing a surprise party for their best friend, even though the friend said they hate birthday parties. The friend also mentioned they'd be mad if there was a party, and it's at his house.

First, the user planned the party and thought the friend was just saying they didn't want a party to avoid being disappointed. But the friend actually hates them. The user didn't listen and is going through with it because it's too late to cancel.

So, did the user make a mistake by not considering the friend's feelings? The friend explicitly stated they don't like parties, which the user ignored. Even though the friend might have said it before, the user didn't take it seriously. Now the friend is upset, which the user caused. The user should have either not planned the party or talked to the friend before proceeding. Since they didn't, they're in the wrong. Answer A.
